titleStmt.title: TO THE RIGHT NOBLE, AD my much honoured Ladie, KATHERINE▪ Ladie MANSELL, daughter to the Right Honourable Lord, L. Viscount de Lisle: Earths Glorie, and Heauens Happinesse.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: TO THE RIGHT NOBLE, AD my much honoured Ladie, KATHERINE▪ Ladie MANSELL, daughter to the Right Honourable Lord, L. Viscount de Lisle: Earths Glorie, and Heauens Happinesse.

monogr.title: Linsi-woolsie. Or Two centuries of epigrammes. Written by William Gamage Batchelour in the Artes
monogr.author: Gamage, William

div.head: TO THE RIGHT NOBLE, A •… D my much honoured Ladie, KATHERINE▪ Ladie MANSELL, daughter to the Right Honourable Lord, L. Viscount de Lisle: Earths Glorie, and Heauens Happinesse.
div.p:
RARE PARAGON of vertne, affying, or rather presuming on your heroicall disposition, I haue aduentured to conduct to the open field of the World Two Centuries of Epigrammes, which, if they bee deign'd to march vnder the Banner of your Ho: protection, I doubt not, but that they may the safer, as they say, Passe the Muste •… . And the rather I build on your all-fauourable patronage by reason of your Ladyships neere affinitie with that worthie, and Tres •… ble Sir Phillip Sidney, whose golden Pen vouchsae fed to Apologize the renowned art of Poetry. If thimy Rurall, and vnacquainted muse Limm's no •… forth either in Matter, or Manner the viue •… ort
traitur of an Epigramme, your Ladyship may ea
•… coniecture, that it was rather Cherillus Pen, and not Apelles Pencill that shadowed it; but hoping the acceptation, with your Ho: protection hereof, if not for the Worke, yet for the names-sake, I euer rest
Your worthy Ladyships most deuoted Votorie:
